paper.title: Thin-Trading Effects in Beta: Bias v. Estimation Error
paper.abstract: Two regression coefficients often used in Finance, the Scholes-Williams (1977) quasi-multiperiod 'thin-trading' beta and the Hansen-Hodrick (1980) overlapping-periods regression coefficient, can both be written as instrumental-variables estimators. Competitors are Dimson's beta and the Hansen-Hodrick original OLS beta. We check the performance of all these estimators and the validity of the t-tests in small and medium samples, in and outside their stated assumptions, and we report their performances in a hedge-fund style portfolio-management application. In all experiments as well as in the real-data estimates, less bias comes at the cost of a higher standard error. Our hedge-portfolio experiment shows that the safest procedure even is to simply match by size and industry; any estimation just adds noise. There is a clear relation between portfolio variance and the variance of the beta estimator used in market-neutralizing the portfolio, dwarfing the beneficial effect of bias.

domain_result.justification: 该论文主要讨论了不同beta估计方法在投资组合管理中的应用，特别是在对冲基金风格的组合管理中。论文明确提到了这些估计方法在组合管理中的表现，并讨论了组合方差与beta估计方差之间的关系。
